subject: Ethics
title: Emotional Attachment to Machines
description: A micro-lesson that makes Emotional Attachment to Machines usable.

hook.text: Soldiers held funerals for their bomb-disposal robots. They gave them names, ranks, and Purple Hearts.

buildup.text: Humans bond with anything that seems alive. We name our cars, mourn broken toys, and talk to Alexa.

discovery.text: Studies show elderly people in care homes form deep attachments to robot pets, reducing loneliness measurably.

twist.text: But the robot doesn't love them back. Is a one-sided relationship therapeutic or a cruel illusion?

climax.text: Companies design robots to trigger bonding on purposeâ€”big eyes, soft voicesâ€”to increase product loyalty.

punchline.text: The attachment is real. The relationship isn't. Does it matter?

quiz.question: Why is emotional attachment to robots an ethical concern?
options: Robots always malfunction when humans bond with them
Companies exploit bonding by design, and the attachment is one-sided
Humans never actually form real attachments to machines
